sp.p: Now it works to my wish: prethee observe how they look.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Hush,— I do.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: O Lord, Uncle, your mercy;— I was betray'd, seduc'd, as a man may say.— Go, go,— begone, I'll speak with you to morrow.—
I say, Uncle, I was seduc'd, chowsed, cheated.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Catcht with a Wench?— Come, Sir, I'll talk with you.— Oh disgrace to the Family.— With a Wench? a lewd Wench? Come along, Sir;— I'll watch you henceforth.—

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Ha, ha! Why, here has been a great deal of Intrigue to night I see, Ha, Sir?— I am sorry now I went to Bed so soon:— But I have been in the sweetest Dream yonder.—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p:
Here has introth been a great deal of Intrigue, as thou sayst, Tom: But no matter; now all's well: And since it has happen'd so well, a Day of Jubilee shall Crown it. To morrow is my Wedding-Day, and in memory of that happy hour that conjoined me and my sweet Chicken there together, we'll have a Feast;— and I'll sing, and roar, and drink
cum privilegio
. Go, wait on her in, Tom:— Chicken, remember we are Friends; Go,— I'll be with you presently.—

div.stage: Ex. Rashley bowing scornfully to Ranger and Maria.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Never was such a day, nor such a deed.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Ned! let me have no more of your doubts nor counsels. D'ee hear! 'Sbud, I say once more my Wife is the honestest Woman in Christendom, and you shall hear from me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Was ever the like known?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Never since Adam; but she was a Devil before the Creation.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll not give over thus.—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Nor I.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Your hand on't—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.l: Here! and may all the Demons that have pow'r
In subtle plots help now, tho' never more.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll die but I'll perform it.—
sp.l: My Slights shall with Immortal Wit be wrought:
And all my Sences shall convert to Thought.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: SIrrah! haunt me no more, I know thee not.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Nay, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Go to your Wench, and let her entertain you; then stock Sir Ieremy's Mannor-house at home with Bastards,— Birds of night, and teach 'em all to know their Father when you ha' done.—

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Good Uncle, let me speak.—

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: No place to bring your Cattel to but thither, under your Mistrisses Nose, thou most notorious Ass? Mercy o'me, what will this World come to? who could imagine that Sheeps Face of thine; that Mouth, whence ne'er came any thing that had sence; that Person that has as oft been thought a Puritan as thou hast been a Fool? Then that hanging Dog-look. I'll say no more, but the Devil is subtle.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Uncle, you know 'tis an old saying, We cannot appoint our own Destinies; nor did I foresee this: besides, Sir, if you knew her as well as I do, you'd find the Woman has some parts that are not contemptible.— 'Sbud, I know what's what; I am not such a Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Not such a Fool! In verity if thou wert but a grain nearer to a Natural, I'd beg thee of the King, and adopt another to inherit thy Estate. Not such a Fool!

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: No, so I say, Sir, since you go to that: Whoop! what a Pox you have forgot since you were young your self?

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: I young! why, Sir, I hope I got no Bastards.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p:
No:— But you kept Whores that you did, and that's all one,
bona fide
.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: This Rogue has heard all; I must stop his mouth. How, Sirrah, I kept Whores?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: It has been thought so, Sir, since you go to that: Nay, 'tis no such Miracle now adays; there's many an old Badger about Town does the like; 'tis grown a custom now.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: But 'tis not so customary with your Uncle, Sir: but come, pray express your self; what Women do the infamous World lay to my charge?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p:
What Women! ' Bud are you ignorant? Hum,
Nan, Pegg, Ioan of the Dairy, Sara, Ienny, Dorothy, Mary, Bridget.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Hold! hold, I say; 'Sdeath he'll reckon the whole Country presently: I must quiet him, the Rogue has me upon the hip; Harkee, Cob.

sp.speaker: Sneak
sp.p: Then the Parsons Wife, Sir, and the old Hostess at the Townsend: You see the Fool has a good memory.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: A waggish one I see thou hast: Ha, if thou could'st remember Law-Cases as well, thou wouldst be a brave Fellow. Why, Cob, thou think'st thou hast paid me off now, dost not?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I know not, if my Wit flow too fast, Sir, I cannot help it; 'tis a good that's thrown upon me, 'tis not my seeking: 'tis true, I have an unhappy way with me sometimes, but 'tis over presently, it never lasts long, that's one comfort.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: In verity I see thou hast Wit, and now I'll cherish it. Why, Cob, my instruction is for thy good, Child, what will thy Mistriss think when she hears of it?— Come, come, in verity, Cob, 'twas ill done, 'twas ifaith.— But mum, no more words on't, I'll make all well agen.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: So, so, I have brought him about finely; 'Sbud I did not think I had so much Wit, but I see a man may be mistaken in his own parts.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: But d'ee hear, Cob, not a word more of these Wenches, let the foolish World say what it will.— Thou art a good Boy in verity, I like thy Wit well: Thou know'st I have no Heir, and when I die, Cob, I will not say I'll give thee any thing, lest I should make thee proud; but expect, expect wonders may fall, who knows?—

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: By Ierico I would not have spoke on't now, but that I had nothing else to say, and you know 'tis a disgrace to a Scholar to be silent in company.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, 'tis no matter: prethee how cam'st thou to know that Pegg and I were so intimate?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Ah, you'll be angry if I shou'd tell you.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: In verity not I:— Angry?— Come, come, out with it, Cob, out with't.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Why, the truth is, I lay with her one night, and the Quean told me all.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Didst thou! God a mercy. (Dam him! what a Snake have I foster'd?) Done like a Cock o'th' Game in verity. Ah, when I was of thy years I cou'd have done as much my self.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes, she told me you had done as much: but mum, Sir, not a word more, I know my Kew.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, I shall be a by-word to th' Town.— How now?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir Roger, I was just coming to your House for you; my Master desires yours and Mr. Sneak's company immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: What, the Solemnity holds? this is his Wedding-Day?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Tell him I am coming.—
Come, Cob, let us go; and mum, d'ee hear? you understand me?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir.—

div.head: Scene 2.
div.stage:
Bubble, Emilia, Maria, Rashley, Ranger, Cordelia, Fumble
sitting at a Table.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: COme, come, another Bumper about; my Chickens Health: Here, I am not wet through yet; Tom, what sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir! Oh here comes Sir Roger and his Nephew.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Mr. Bubble and Gentlemen, your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p:
Yours, good Sir Roger; I am glad to see you ifaith; and you, sweet Mr. Sneak. Well, Faith, Sir Roger, we have been Bumping it about here, we have been dipt, as the saying is:
Tom Rashley
, send it round; come, Sir Roger's a Freshman, he'll drink an Ocean.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Fill every Man's Glass there: Mr. Ranger, you want it, 'tis Madam Emilia's health.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: I'll do you reason, Sir;—
And ten to one but I have a stratagem shall dash this mirth.
Are they ready?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Hush! we are observ'd; they are—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: So, so! Come, now the Song, and then the Dance. Look ye, Gentlemen, you must know.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Come, come, Mr. Bubble, let's have t'other Soop, I say; ifack we loose time. Ah Sirrah, are you there? Gad I'll be with you presently; dust it about once more, I say; the Wine has a pretty smack with't;— it cherishes, I like it well: come, another Soop, and then do what you will.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Fill Wine there!— Gentlemen, (as I was saying) I got this Song made purposely, 'tis in praise of Marriage, and there was not one ready made of 'em in Town; I searcht it all over.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Were you at the Poets Lodging?

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Yes, but they had none; for they told me 'twas a Song would not take: besides, they were so busie getting Plays up for the next Term, that I could hardly get one made.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Sir, you needed not have troubled 'em; you once had a very good Vein that way your self.—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p:
Yes, I was mightily given to rapture and flame once: I writ
Tom Farthing
:— I had a hand too in
Colly my Cow
, a Song that took well I can assure you: but this is of another kind in praise of marriage, Sir; and they told me the Town lov'd nothing but Satyrs against Marriage, and the reason was because they were affraid of being Cuckolded:— When, alas, poor silly Rogues, there's no such thing in Nature.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Well, of all stupid Animals a drowsie Husband is the most notorious:—— but I shall change your note presently I doubt not, Sir.——

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: You shall hear, Gentlemen: Hey, the Song there and the Dance?

lg.l: UNder the Branches of a spreading Tree,
Silvander sate, from care and danger free,
And his inconstant roving humour shows
To his dear Nymph, that sung of Marriage-Vows:
But she with flowing Graces charming Air,
Cry'd, Fie, fie, my Dear, give o'er,
Ah, tempt the gods no more!
But thy offence with penitence repair:
For though Vice in a Beauty seem sweet in thy Arms,
An Innocent Virtue has always more Charms.
Ah Phillida! the angry Swain reply'd,
Is not a Mistriss better than a Bride?
What Man that Universal Yoke retains,
But meets an hour to sigh and curse his chains?
She smiling cry'd, Change, change that impious Mind;
Without it we could prove not half the Ioys of Love.
'Tis Marriage makes the feeling Ioys Divine:
For all our Life long we from scandal remove,
And at last fall the Trophies of Honour and Love.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Well sung ifaith: Look'ee, Gentlemen, is it not as I told you?

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: In verity very well, very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Come, now the Dance.—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, here's a Letter for you; it was left by a Porter, who said it requir'd no answer, and is gone.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: So, now for a change of Countenance.— I think this will do.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If not, I've writ a Letter that will: but let's observe.—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: What the Devil has this Fellow given me here? A Letter? Pray Heav'n it be no challenge.— How?— What's here?

Sir,
That you are blind, I have heard; that you are a Fool, I know; and that you are a Cuckold, I believe.— However, as a Friend, tho' unknown, I am bound in Conscience to give you this Information; Your Wife is false; You are abus'd; The Author of your wrong you know as well as your self, if you know your self as well as you know
Rashley.

Oh Heav'n! was ever such fate?— But hush, I'll smother my resentment till they are gone.— Come, Sir Roger and Gentlemen, there's a Tongue in the next Room, pray go and eat;— I'll be with you presently.—

div.stage:
Ex. all but
Bubble, Ranger
and Maria.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: So, I see by this behaviour it takes, and I'll away, lest he should suspect me.— Now for my t'other plot.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: O Sister, here's a new discovery; the Devil is come abroad agen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How? the Devil?

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Ay, in the likeness of a Letter: Here, prethee read it; 'tis his Character; I am sure it looks as if 'twere writ with a Cloven Hoof.— Hah!— what think'st thou?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, he calls you Fool here.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Ay, he's a little uncivil, that's the truth on't: but what's to be done, Sister?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: A Cuckold too.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Ay;— was ever such an impudence?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I never heard of any: but 'tis no more, Sir, than I expected: Alas! 'tis nothing to be a Cuckold now.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Oh unfortunate estate of Marriage! by the Lord Harry, if this be true, I have prais'd it to fine purpose. But, Sister, thou wert wont to be kind; prethee advise me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis to no purpose, Sir, you know I am envious, my words have double meaning: I did my Sister wrong in my last Story, pray let me offend no more.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Well, I confess I was to blame; but who the Devil cou'd have mistrusted her when the plot was carried so hansomly?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh you will find, Sir, she has still more plots, and I find you so credulous and so wedded to your infamy, that for my part I am afraid to have any thing to do with it.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Help me but this once, and if I fail thee agen, may I be prov'd a Cuckold to the whole County, and my Case try'd in Westminster-Hall.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Well! once more then I'll assist you, and to confirm what that Letter has inform'd,— know, Sir, she is false; and tho' she frustrated our last plot by her Waiting-Womans means, she certainly met
Rashley that night.— I am glad you credit a Strangers Letter; for my part I love her so well, I should have hardly caus'd a second breach between ye else: but since 'tis out, and you desire my assistance, follow me, and ere night I doubt not but to give you sufficient proof of your misfortune

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: With all my heart, dear Sister.— 'Sbud, a Cuckold?— 'Tis impossible, I ha' no Cuckolds face;— but I'll be resolv'd immediately.—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Do this, thou shalt command me.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: In truth, Sir, I am afraid 'twill be discover'd, and I would not have my Lady know it for the World.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: I swear she never shall. What, dost thou doubt me? Besides, I'll be so grateful to thee, thou shalt never have cause to repent this Courtesie.—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Sir, you know you always might command me in any reasonable thing: pray speak it agen, Sir, what wou'd you have me do?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Why only plant me in or near her Chamber for a design I have, she shall be ignorant why,— or by what means I got thither; I'll still be careful of thy reputation: Come, take this Purse, and prethee do it willingly.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Well, Sir, what you mean I know not; but Heav'n direct all for the best: I can deny you nothing, Sir; I lie in a Closset that joins to her Chamber, where you may both over-hear and speak to her.—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: That above all things! prethee let's go.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: But for Heav'ns sake take care she knows not that I brought ye thither; I would not be seen in such a business for the World.—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Ne'er doubt, I warrant thee I'll be careful.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Follow me then, Sir.—

div.head: Scene 3.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: SPat. Sirrah!

sp.speaker: Spat.
sp.p: Here, Sir, here.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Whither is this Rascal gone? Well, ifack, I am too full of clemency; I must swinge this Rogue, or he'll never be good for any thing; he's at Nine-holes now, I'll lay my life: A damn'd Villain, that spends me Three-pence a day I know not how.

sp.speaker: Spat.
sp.p: O Lord, who I, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Who's within there? what, will no body hear me? Am I left desolate? I have not the plague I think.— Ha!

sp.speaker: Spat.
sp.p: Why, here am I, Sir; I have been here all this while.—

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Oh Sirrah, are you come? where have you been, ha? I say, where have you been, Rogue?

sp.speaker: Spat.
sp.p: No where, Sir, not I.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Sirrah! I must be left alone! must I! and when I have a message to send, go my self.— Hah!— Sirrah, Mr. Little-Pox has a Boy, that tho' he was stinted at Nurse, and is not above pockethigh, can run, and frisk, and jump upon occasion, Sirrah, know a Bayly by his Nose, and a Wench by her Buttocks, ye Rogue, and a good Linguist, and a pretty Pimp, Sirrah, and can hold the Door with a steady hand, ye Rogue: but thou, a Rascal, a Drone, art good for nothing.

sp.speaker: Spat.
sp.p: Any thing, Sir, I warrant you: try me, and you shall find I can hold a Door as well as he.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Why, how now, Sirrah? what, make mouths at me? is your Master grown your mirth? Ha, this will teach you better; this will new-mold you; I'll fetch you out of your damn'd looks ifack: French Grimaces, Rogue, French Grimaces?

sp.speaker: Spat.
sp.p: O Lord, what shall I do? Because he's deaf, and cannot hear me, he thinks I mock him.— Hold, Sir,— for Heav'ns sake; upon my Faith I don't mock you;
'Tis all a mistake; and, Sir, you have beaten me for nothing.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: What a noise the Rogue makes! Why, Sirrah, cannot you speak temperately, but you must roar thus? I am not so deaf, but I can hear without this Thunder-clap. But you do it in contempt, do you, Sirrah? Bless us, to what an impudence this Age is grown! But I'll fetch the Devil out, lest he should grow in ye,— thus.—
I should be loth to see thee hang'd till you come to years of discretion.

sp.speaker: Spat.
sp.p: Mercy o'me, what a Master have I? If I stay long here I shall be beaten into Mummy.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Come, Sir, now I have perform'd the part of a Master and a Friend in your Castigation, I have now a word or two by way of Instruction. Mark me, Sirrah,— nothing exasperates more than scorn, nor nothing pleases more than observance; a Master should be strict in finding occasion to beat his Servant, and a Servant should be careful in avoiding the beatings of his Master.

sp.speaker: Spat.
sp.p: So, he has taught me, now I shall be careful of avoiding it hereafter if my legs will carry me.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: What, mouths agen, Sirrah, mouths agen?

sp.speaker: Spat.
sp.p: Umph.—

div.stage: Makes a low Congee,— says nothing.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Oh this submission pacifies: Come hither, I have a message for ye, and let me see how you can behave your self; 'tis a matter of moment.

sp.speaker: Spat.
sp.p: I'll do my best to please ye, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: What dost thou say now?— Look, look!— was ever such a Rascal as this? This Rogue knows well enough that I cannot hear him. Sirrah, come and lay your mouth to my ear, and then speak, if you would have me understand ye.

sp.speaker: Spat.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I shall be very careful to remember it hereafter.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Rafters?— what Rafters, Rogue?

sp.speaker: Spat.
sp.p: Sir, I shall be careful to remember it hereafter.—

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: O shall you so, Sir? and 'twill become you ifack: for look'ee, Sirrah, 'tis my humour as long as I am healthy and jovial, to cover failings and imperfections in Nature as well as I can; 'tis a Wise-mans vertue, and I have paterns for't every day. Ah! here are a sort of jolly, brisk, ingenious, old Signiors about Town, that with false Calves, false Bellies, false Teeth, false Noses, and a false fleering Face, upon the matter fill up Society as well as ere a Masquerading Fop of 'em all.— But to the matter: Sirrah, you must carry this Ring to Cordelia, and possess her with my love in an elegant manner: Stand there, and let me see how you can carry your self in such a business.

sp.speaker: Spat.
sp.p: Thus, Sir: I had my Honours from the Dancing-School.—

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: O damn'd Rogue! what a Bow's there? 'tis worse than a Country Counsellors to a Client that has no money. Sirrah,— pull me your Hat off thus,— with a Grace:— Ah! I cou'd have done it rarely twenty years ago;— but ifack Time and Gravity defaces all things.— Come, Sirrah.—

sp.speaker: Spat.
sp.p: Madam! my Master too well knowing the Charms of your Wit and Beauty are too sharp at all times to be opposed, has by me sent this Ring, and humbly desires—

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Well, that last Honour was pretty well:— but come now, let's hear what you can say?

sp.speaker: Spat.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! he has not heard me all this while;— what shall I do?
Oh some-body knocks; this was happy: Sir, there's some-body at door to speak with you.—

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p:
Go see who 'tis, I'll follow.— This is a plaguy dull Rogue, but I must have patience, and take pains with him.— Nor shou'd he do any thing in this business had I not a design in't; and ifack I like the Woman well;— she's young, and plump, free in her Nature, and of a Sanguine Complexion, and
bona fide
, I never see her but some secret motions in my blood seem to imply that she is the cause.— What? I am not Bedrid;— I can dance yet, ay, and run and jump too if occasion be, and why not the t'other thing?— Come, come,— it must, it must;— mine was ever a stirring Family:— it must, I say, and she shall know it suddenly.—

div.head: Scene 4.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: COme softly, Sir, and plant your self here at this back-door, I have already made a discovery.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Are they together?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I believe so; they seldom miss such an opportunity, especially when they think you absent.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: No; they are politick with a Pox to 'em: Sister, what revenge, ha? I am resolv'd to be a Tyrant: 'Sbud I'll pinch her to death with a pair of Tongs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O fie, that will be too cruel.—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Cruel! by the Lord Harry 'tis Justice,— palpable Justice! Why, shou'd she live, she'd Cuckold the whole Nation.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Consider better on't, 'tis but a venial Crime, and deserves not such rigour.— But come,— meditate of no revenge till you are certain of the fault:— keep close at that door, be sure you discover not your self till I come to you; I'll go and observe.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: I'll try my patience;— but 'tis a damn'd Cause.—

div.stage: Enter Rashley and Emilia, Scene a Bed-Chamber.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Our Intrigue as yet goes well.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: I swear to admiration; and had I not seen each passage, I shou'd have thought 't had been impossible. Oh my Dearest! how shall I gratifie thee? My love's too poor, and my desert too mean ever to equal it.—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: I am glad I've got air agen; this damn'd old Gib-Cat has mew'd me this half hour into such a hole, that had I staid a minute longer I had certainly been smother'd: it stinks worse than a Pothecaries Shop, and is furnisht with nothing but Gally-pots full of nasty Oyl, into which groping about I often thrust my Fingers:— Fough!— Assafoetida, as I live!— a most intolerable stink!—— Ah! the Devil grind her old Chops.— Stay;— this is sure Emilia's Chamber, and if I am not mistaken, I heard a whispering here;— it may be they're together;— I'll be still and listen.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Our love shall last whole Ages, and each Kiss add new and fierce desires: Death shall want power to separate us, and Envy droop and pine it self away to see its ●●●●agem succeed no better.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: By Heav'n 'tis so;— They are here:— Blest minute! now I shall make a rare discovery.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I am confirm'd, and will proceed in loving. A Husband is a dull insipid thing, pall'd and grown stale within a week: But a Lover appears still new and gay, and is to perpetuity the same he was at first,— all mirth,— all pleasure.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: A most excellent Theme:— Oh that that Property, that Fool her Husband, stood now to hear this Devil of a Wife make out this free Confession!—

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: He, dull Creature, Heav'n knows, is blind to all your Charms. Marriage acts only the Decrees of Duty, Love has the least share in 't. In this Age a Husband with a Wife is like a Bully in a Church;— the only pleasure he takes is to sleep away the hours shou'd be employ'd in Conjugal Duty.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Well! I am very glad our plots succeed so well: I swear I was half frighted t'other day when my Sister-in-Law Maria discover'd us. Was it not done subt'ly? Did I not fetch all off agen with an excellent Invention?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Good! rarely good! This Devil cannot sure have so much impudence to deny this agen.

sp.speaker: Rash
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! By Heav'n I'm ready to die with laughing when I think what Asses we made of 'em.— Ranger too, that busie Coxcomb,— what a fretting, and plotting, and sweating did he make for nothing!— Alas, poor Fool!— Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: O the Devil fleer you.— 'Sdeath, am I still their Property? I shall have a slice at your Nose ere long: I doubt not, my young Gallant,— I shall dash your Mummery.—

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Come, we lose time:— Let talk be our diversion when we are old and can reap nothing else; our minutes now should all be spent in rapture.—— Thus, thus, my Sweet!— Oh that we cou'd live thus ever!— How now, what noise is that?

sp.speaker: Bubble within.
sp.p: Bawds! Strumpets! Whores! Witches! Break open the door there, break open the door.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fetch a Leaver, or call the Smith over the way presently.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Oh Heav'n, my Husband and Maria! we are undone.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Tis Bubble's voice sure! this compleats my joy. Now let Belzebub, if he owes her any kindness, fetch her from hence, I'll guard this passage.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: What! what shall I do, Madam?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Here quickly, run into this Closset, Sir, and jump out of the Window into the Garden; if you were gone, let me alone for the rest.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Who steps a foot this way, steps on his death; his Soul shall not be his a minute.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Ha! Ranger here? I am lost in my amazement.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Death! and Hell and I defenceless too! O cursed Minute!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: No, Madam, I'll secure you from this stratagem: This Window shall be no Bawd to th' Intrigue now, that I'll be sure on.—

sp.speaker: Bubble within.
sp.p: Quickly, quickly! a Leaver, a Leaver!

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: No way t' escape? Can I not climb the Chimney? Any thing to get free this once.— Oh fate, taken i'th' midst of our security, when we least thought of it! what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I have it: Come hither, get ye under this Table, and diligently listen to what I say: 'Tis ten to one he never searches here. Come, in, in, quickly, and pray the rest may prosper.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: I never had more need of pray'rs:— I'll try.—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: So! that conveyance is fast enough. Now, Madam, what think'ee of a fleering Jest upon the Fool Ranger, the Coxcomb, the Ass Ranger, and your jolly spleen to laugh, Ha, ha? I think the Dice are mine now: Now, Devil, I have trapt ye.—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: This Key may add to my design.—

div.stage: Takes out the Key o'th' door.

sp.speaker: Bubble within.
sp.p: Down, down with it, break it open there.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: What think you of that, Madam? Does your Husbands voice refresh you extreamly?—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Now help me, Wit, or I am lost.
sp.stage: She goes and puts the Key into his Coat-Pocket, and then lays hold of him, and cries out.—
sp.p: Help, help there, for Heav'ns sake, I am undone, ruin'd for ever: A Rape, a Rape!— Help, help!—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Hell and the Devil, what does she mean?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Ah, cruel Man, cannot these Tears prevail? will nothing stop Barbarity? what have I done that cou'd deserve this usage? O most unfortunate of Women.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Dam her, I shall be finely catcht if this hold; I must get away.—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: A Rape, a Rape! Help there, for Heav'ns sake, help.—

div.stage: Enter Bubble and Maria with a Light. They stand amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: By Heav'n, I am snapt agen, catcht in my own snare.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Has my Husband been so much thy Friend, and wouldst abuse him thus, (thou base man?) but Heav'n forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: 'Sbud, what's this I see? Ranger?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ranger here, and Rashley absent: I have plotted finely. 'Tis plain now that Traytor loves her, and has only made me an Engine to work his design with more facility.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Rashly gone too? Now has the Devil to spite me convey'd him away in a Mist: Here's like to be fine work towards; but I must stand the brunt now I am enter'd.—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Now, Sir, what a Pox make you here with my Wife? Hah?—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: So, it begins rarely! O this subtle Devil! Why, Sir, as I am a Gentleman, and upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: O my Dear, a thousand thanks for this deliverance; and by all our love I charge thee, by our Marriage-Vows, by all our Pleasures since, and Joys to come, I charge you revenge me upon that Traytor there:— He would have Ravisht me!— Oh Heav'n, that ever I should live to be so put to't!—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: 'Sbud! Ravish my Chicken? Ranger, you are the Son of a Whore, and I shall presume to cut your Throat.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Sir, do but hear me, upon my Honour all this is false.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It must be true! what should he come hither for, but upon some ill intent? I am resolv'd I'll be reveng'd on him however.—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! she against me too? this is worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Discover the matter, that I may do Justice on both sides.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Sir, know then,— Ranger long has lov'd me; often sollicited me unlawfully:— but finding something in my Vertue that shook his designs, his recourse was to make you jealous of me and Rashley;- who, poor man, has often told me with sighs how deeply he has resented your unkind suspitions.—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Alas, poor Fellow!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: O confusion! he begins to believe her agen.—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: At last, Sir, finding his suit to be too troublesom for me to bear, and being loth to vex you with such fooleries,— I told Rashley, who promised all assistance imaginable:— I desir'd him also to be careful, and watch lest I should be surpriz'd; as to night (Heav'n knows) I was.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Dam her, what a Lye is this! Pray, Sir, let me speak.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Not in my House, Sir, you have talkt too much already; and by the Lord Harry I'll talk with you anon: but let that pass, go on, Chicken.—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: At last, Sir, this unhappy night coming hither as I used to do to my Devotions,— He it seems having corrupted some of my Servants, got into the Closset, and thence came and surpriz'd me;— first locking the door, and putting the Key into his Pocket.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: I a Key? Sir, as I live I saw none: This is the most notorious Lye—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Oh wretched man! was it not Crime enough to make such an attempt, but you must persist in falshood? Sir, he has it now about him there in that Pocket, I saw him put it in.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: This Pocket?— Why, thou Devil! hah!—
sp.stage: Puts his hand in's Pocket, pulls out a Key.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, how came it here? Magick, Witchcraft,— the Devil and all,— combine against me! wou'd I were well out,— if ever I plot agen,—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis evident now he would have Ravisht her! Lockt her in for the purpose.— Perfidious Traytor, see me no more.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: A very fine bus'ness this!

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Is it so, Sir? I'll do your business for you.—

div.stage: Goes to run at Ranger, and overthrows the Table.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Discover'd? I am lost agen.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: 'Sbud, Rashley!

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: 'Sdeath and Hell, what will become of me now?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: How! Rashley under the Table? Then Fate is mine agen. Now, Sir, do you perceive any thing yet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Stranger and stranger! what can this mean? or what could they both do here?

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! how came he here?— Hoh!—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Ay,— examine that point closely; sure this will make for me.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: As Gad jidge me, and so I will: speak, I say, how came he here?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Nay, Heav'n knows, not I; I believe for the same design with Ranger.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, she'll betray me too.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Tell him, tell him, Sir:— speak for your self;— say any thing.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Speak? why,— 'Sbud, Madam, have I not done as you commanded me? Have I not watcht here this two hours to frustrate Ranger's design? What, d'ee think to make an Ass of me?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: How, Sir,— my design? Dam me this must not pass upon me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Nor you shall not pass upon my Friend here neither, Sir; I heard you this evening when you corrupted one of the Women to get you into that Closset, that you might accomplish with more ease, Sir. But, Madam, this is a little unnatural, to make me suspected as his Collegue, when my design was so far different.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: 'Sbud I cannot find the meaning of this.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
The meaning! Why, Sir,— she hid me under the Table as a defence against Ranger's insolence: but when she heard you at the door, and knew you were coming in, she conjur'd me by all the love I bore her to sit still, and not discover my self;— and all her excuse was
your jealousie; (Jealousie with a Pox!) a very fine slight for the abuse she intended to me:— 'Sdeath, Madam, my service deserv'd a better reward if you consider it.— (Pray Heav'n this Lye prosper.)

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!— I knew I should vex him; but I confess 'tis all true:— For (my poor dear Rogue!) I am so hourly tormented with fear of thy naughty jealousie, that I dare not tell thee any thing.— Prethee desert it, do, my dear Sweet;— Ifads thou wouldst be the best Husband in the World if thou wouldst but leave it.—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Well! it must be so; this cannot be feign'd:— Come hither to me,— I will forsake it:— By the Lord Harry thou art the best Wife in Christendom,— and I the most ungrateful Husband; but forgive, my Dear, forgive.—
We have all failings thou knowest, prethee forgive me.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: So! now may I hang my self. 'Sdeath! all the Fiends are Asses to her.— I'll begone for shame, lest worse befall me:
sp.l: —— Succubus, Farewel;—
There is not such a Sorceress in Hell.—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Come! hast thou seal'd my pardon?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: You know the softness of my temper; but your unkind jealousie will kill me one day.—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Igad I'll kill my self first. Come, prethee no more. Tom, thy hand too;— come, I know thou canst bear with my frailty.—

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: I Sir, I can bear well enough! but me thought 'twas a little strange to tax me.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Come, come, all shall be well;— Faith, we'll go in and frolick. Oh my Dear, suspect thee;— Well, I am a Fool, that's the truth on't.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The Devil helps her sure; for this was certainly an Assignation: I'll after Ranger and know the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!— Was ever plot carried thus? Sure never! Her Wit has more supplies than I have thoughts, and happily they end still; and Gad for my own part I shall love lying the better as long as I live for the success of this— Once more all is well, and he the Cuckold still, Ha, ha, ha! I must go in and laugh with her.
sp.l: Intrigue's her Masterpiece; and all may see,
A Woman's Wit's best in extremity.—

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: WEll, of all Creatures that vex Mortality, a superannuated Lover is certainly the most troublesom, especially to one of my years: our inequality is so preposterous, and his address so unnatural, that I always entertain rather hate for his person, than compliance for his love: From Fourscore and five, Heav'n deliver me; 'tis an Age of doting.— Here he comes, I knew I could not be quiet one hour.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Sirrah, Sirrah! Rogue, Rogue! and how and how! Hah! art thou jolly, blithe, like a Bird in a Tree? Ifack I was impatient till I came to see thee: well, and how sits the Ring? does it shine? does it glitter? Hah, little black Rogue!— Ifack I bought it of the best Goldsmith in Cheapside, a Man of good Reputation; A Cuckold too, and they are always the honestest Fellows.—

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: From henceforth let me desire you, Sir, to bestow your presents on some body else:— I sent your Ring back by your Man, he can best give you an account of it.—

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p:
Hah!— what sayst thou? Counterfeit? Ifack thou art mistaken, Bird;— thou art,
bona fide
, they are as well cut as any in Christendom, and of the right Black-water: What, dost thou think I'll put any false Stones upon thee ifack?— I am more civil, Ieod, there I was waggish;— But she's a witty Rogue, she'll apprehend the jest.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Was ever such an insipid piece of Antiquity? Pray, Sir, forbear these impertinences, and assure your self I hate an old Fellow for a Husband, as much as an old Gown, or an old piece of Wit, that after forty years Oblivion, with a new name, is publisht for a new Lenten Play.—

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p:
What does she say now? But no matter, I'll go on. Well said, Bird, well said:
Bona fide
, thou hast Wit in abundance; that Colour, and such a sort of Nose, never fail. But come, we lose time, I know 'tis ordain'd I must marry thee: I am the Man that must gather the Rosebuds.— Ah Rogue!— I'll warrant thou'rt a swinger, and Ifack that black a top there fires me strangely, I am all flame, and
bona fide
, me thinks as youthful and Mercurial as any Spark of 'em all.
SONG.
ANd he took her by the middle small,
And laid her on the Plain
;
With a hey down derry down, come diddle,
With a ho down derry, &c.
What think you, Madam? am I old?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: So old, that your presence is more terrible than a Deaths-Head at Supper: for my part I tremble all over. There's a kind of horrour in all your antick gestures; 'specially those that you think become you,— that fright worse than the Devil; than the Devil, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: The Devil! what of him, Bird? Pish, the Devil's an Ass, I ha' seen't in a Play;— and ifack we lose time in talking about so worthless a matter. Lovers shou'd ne'er be slow in their affairs:— For, as my good Friend Randolph tells me, Nothing is like opportunity taken in the nick; in the nick, Sweet-heart!— Icod, I was waggish again, I was waggish agen ifack.— Come, Bird, come.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: What will you do, Sir? Heav'n, how he tortures me!

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Come along then;— I have got a Priest ready, and paid for the Licence and all:— Prethee let me kiss thee; I long to practise something that might please thee: Never was man so alter'd! never! Come, prethee Bird,— come, ifack I have not patience.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Here's Sir
Roger Petulant
! my dear Mouse desires to speak a word or two with you.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Oh here's some hope of deliverance! Sir Roger, your humble Servant. Come hither, Lettice, and stand just in my place: I am so tortur'd with this old Fellow,— prethee be kind to him, and follow him whither he'd have thee; it may be a Husband in thy way, and a good Estate.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: A Husband! marry that's fine! I warrant you, sweet Mouse, I ll be very punctual.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: So, now let us slip aside and observe; 'twould be an excellent revenge if he shou'd marry her.— He's coming to her already, and his eyes are so old and dim that he perceives not his mistake.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p:
Delays, Sweet-heart, are dang'rous ifack; I have consider'd it: The time I have liv'd in the World has given me the benefit of knowing more than another of fewer minutes.— Along, along,—
I say, thou shalt be my Queen, my Paramour, my Cleopatra,— and I will live another Age in Love, and then farewel old Simon ifack. Come, come along.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Oh sadness! what happy fortune's this? Well, I'll go with him, pray Heav'n he be blind enough, that's all I fear.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: She seems kinder than usual;— ifack I have wrought her finely. Come, poor Rogue, come.—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I am ready, Sir;— this was a happy hour;
And if it hit but right, I'm made for ever.—

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I am glad I am rid of him any way: but now, Sir Roger, to your bus'ness.— I hear your Nephew is sick.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: In verity, Madam, most dangerously sick, and the cause of my giving you this trouble was in verity to give you information of it; for by his melancholy I find love is the cause. Ah, Madam, your last indifference was very prejudicial to him: 'Tis true, he denies it;— but I am old enough to judge of the contrary, and therefore have found out 'tis Passion, nay Passion for you has laid him thus low, and nothing but your smiles can raise him, 'tis gone so far in verity.—

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: I am sorry, Sir, I have the misfortune to be th' occasion of such a disaster:— but is there any remedy? what would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Madam, my suit to you is, that you would be pleas'd to go with me and give him a visit; the surprize of your presence I am confident will dissipate his melancholy, and perhaps totally banish his distemper.
But I see we are interrupted; let's retire, Madam, and if you please now will be a very good time to visit him.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Softly, Sir, I would not have my Cozen Maria know any thing of it; but if that can do him any good, I'll not be so cruel to deny it,— 'tis an act of charity.— Come, Sir, I'll go with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Madam, you oblige us both—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Still baffled! sure this cannot last long; the Devil will be weary of obliging her in a little time. I have been yonder sifting Ranger about the last plot, and by all circumstances find what he said was true, and shall I leave off thus poorly? Pish, I cannot for shame:— I have Truth and Honesty on my side;— she's only cunning, and 'tis impossible that shou'd last ever.— Once more then have at 'em:— I have by several false messages buz'd it again into my Brothers ears; he believes, and will once more follow my counsel: besides, I have here a
false Key to her Chamber, and can surprize 'em when they least suspect: this, if Ranger be at all diligent, must needs effect it;— for I am resolv'd not to rest till 'tis done, for the satisfaction of my revenge on that false man.—

div.stage: Enter Apothecary and Sneak in a Night-Gown.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Uh! Uh!

sp.speaker: Apoth.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, if you would have the effects answer your expectation, you must suffer, Sir, and be patient.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: 'Ounds! I cannot have patience:— Sure a civil Clap might be cured without all this stir. 'Tis not a Miracle in this age.— Oh Lord!

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: O horrible! what's this I see?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: My Uncle! Oh I am undone, lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Apoth.
sp.p: But, Sir, your civil Clap might ha' been an uncivil Pox in time.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: How, Sir Roger? was it fit to make me Spectator of this object?

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: The Pox? In verity I have brought his Mistriss to fine purpose: Ah damn'd Rascal! The Pox? what shall I do? I am disgrac'd for ever.—

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Hark ye, Sir, pray what is that there?

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p:
What shall I say? (Death, she has found out his Sweating-Chair!) Why, Madam, 'tis— umph— 'tis a Mathematical Engine they use at
Cambridge.— Cob
was always addicted to study.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: 'Twere a fault to hinder him then, Sir, being so well employ'd.— Farewel.—

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: She has found it out.— Sirrah, see my face no more: from this hour I abhor thee, a damn'd Rascal!

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Good Uncle!—

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: The Pox! A sneaking, sniveling Rogue! Heav'ns, was ever the like seen?— But 'tis now a general Maxim, and your Sandy, Sheeps-face, unthinking Villain, is always the greatest Whoremaster.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Why, by Ierico, it was by chance, Uncle; Hab-nab as a man may say: As I hope to be sav'd 'twas against my will.

sp.speaker: Apoth.
sp.p: Sir, your anger makes an addition to his distemper.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: What, you are his Pandar, Sir, are you? but I think you may be the Devil for your honesty;— so may ye all;— such as you sooth 'em in Vices;— I warrant you are tired with such Customers,— Ha, Sir,— are you not?

sp.speaker: Apoth.
sp.p: In troth, Sir, my rotten Patients are so loath to die, and my sound ones, which for my Arts improvement I would make rotten,— so hasty to recover, that I confess I am often weary, but not tir'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: So, Sir, in verity you are all a company of Rascals;— and as for his part, I'll instantly write to his Father to disinherit him, that I may revenge my disgrace, and punish his folly.— The Pox! a Son of a Whore! the Pox!

sp.speaker: Apoth.
sp.p: A mad old Fellow, but your penitence will recover all.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Wou'd you were hang'd, by Ierico, for leaving the door open.— Oh what shall I do? This comes of learning the Sciences in the Devils name.—

sp.speaker: Apoth.
sp.p: Patience, Sir, have patience.—

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: A Trap-door, say you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Yes, we happily discover'd it yesterday looking for a Ring accidentally dropt;— it opens upon the Stairs the backside of the Kitchin;— I am sure 'twill be very necessary in our Intrigue:— Here, take the Candle you, and go and watch;— and when I give the sign, be sure be ready.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I'll not fail, Madam.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: 'Tis good to be secure, for I know Maria has still an eye over us, and my Husbands new jealousie gives me fresh cause of doubt.—

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Igad, 'tis unnecessary:— This Trap-door must needs be very useful;— I see Fortune is ours still, and will not leave us.— Let us doubt when we see danger; there is none now, nor can be whilst our love continues.—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Which I fear will be but a short time: for what is indirect is seldom permanent; therefore let us consider on't.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Dam Consideration; 'Tis a worse Enemy to Mankind than Malice: Let impotent Age consider, that is fit for nothing but dull tame thoughts of what he has been formerly: Let the Lawyer and Physitian consider, what Quibbles, and what Potions are most necessary: And let the flie Phanatick think his time out, and consider how to be securely factious: But let the Lover love on, still transported, whilst all his thoughts and sences are employ'd in the dear Joys of rapture, endless passion, without a grain of dull Consideration.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I swear the softness of our Tempers abuses half our Sex, we shou'd not else be won so easily:— But we are such kind Fools!

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Ay, we are all Fools, Madam, that's the truth on't; but how shall we help it?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Resolve upon a remedy;— Love no more.—

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Resolve upon the contrary; Love for ever: Gad the World
would be at a fine pass if all were of your mind. How now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Stand there till I fetch you in; I'm sure they're here.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: My Sister as I live! Malicious accident!

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Hah,— with a Light too! How the Devil got she in?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Heav'n knows, unless with a false Key.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, Y'are caught, and finely too, I'm cozen'd else. What plot now, Madam, to convey you hence?— Now show your mighty skill; and if there is a Devil at your service employ him now, you never had more cause.— Me thinks you are melancholy, why d'ee not laugh? smile at your Wit and great security? You, I know, have a thousand ways to get off still; or if you want, that Gentleman can supply you.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: I supply! A plague o' your damn'd jest!

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Hush,— and leave me to her.— Nay, Sister, this is barb'rous to triumph o'er our misfortunes; You know your self what Love is, and what inconveniences it brings poor Women too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You can confess now;— and here's a Gentleman not far off,— your Husband, Madam; I know this cannot chuse but be grateful to him, I'll call him to hear it.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Ah, be not so cruel to undo me quite!— I'll confess all to thee, and from this minute be converted.— Ah, had I taken thy counsel before I had been happy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ay;— but you would persist, and now see what comes on't.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Oh! I am miserable! Forgive me, dear Maria!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, Heav'n forgive you:— but come, will you confess? I have her at a rare advantage.—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Most faithfully;— but let me do't i'th' dark;— let no light see my guilty blushes;— it is enough my tongue dares utter it:— Dear Sister, let me not be too much asham'd:— Oh misery! misery!—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, here is a Light not far off, and thus much I'll comply with you.— Now begin.—

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: By Heav'n I grow cheerful;— we shall 'scape, I am sure, we shall.— Oh this dear Devil!—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: My grief ties up my tongue.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis time to grieve: But come, when d'ee begin?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: This cruel man seduc'd me: Cruel Rashley.— Where are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Here, Sweet, here!—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: First won upon me with his comely presence, hansom demeanour:— every several Grace my Soul admir'd— Give me your hand.—
But when he came to speak, his Tongue, his Charming Tongue, Oh Heav'n, that I shall live to utter it! so ensnar'd me, that I no longer knew my liberty,— but as his Victim gloried in my passion.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: With shame you live to speak it.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: 'Twas my misfortune too:— but Heav'n forgive me, I shall laugh out,— I am not able to hold.—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Down, quickly down.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now could I laugh till my heart ak'd agen to think how I have caught 'em.— I knew 'twas impossible she shou'd 'scape always,— and I will tyrannize more than a Turk over his Slave:— For my part I am sorry for your infamy, and were it not that by the Laws of Nature I have a great concern in any of my Brothers injuries, you might love on for me; but since my Blood runs in his Veins, I dare not see his infamy and let it pass unquestion'd: Therefore either swear from this hour to desert Rashley, and never see him more; or your disgrace I will this instant publish, or call your Husband to be Spectator of his shame and yours.— What, are ye dumb? Not answer me! It seems you dislike this Proposal; but do not provoke me.— Not yet? Nay then— within there?— Brother,— here they are, a light, a light,— quickly.

div.stage: Enter Bubble with a light and long Sword.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Where? where is this Traytor? this Strumpet? by Scanderbeg,— I am ready for a Charge: I'll push him with a Vengeance;— Where is he?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Here, here! How now? What, are you got under the Table agen? or into a corner?— Give me the Candle, Brother,— I am sure have em fast.—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Here's nothing; another mistake, as Gad jidge me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: She is a Devil, and I lose my labour. Gone! what both gone? Oh I could tear my self: Which way?— How! by what means could they escape?

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: ‛ Scape?— 'Sbud! 'tis impossible they shou'd escape if they were here.— Pish,— this is only one of your Maggots, Sister, you do but fancy you saw 'em.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fancy?— Eternal Light forsake me, if I did not both see and speak to 'em two minutes since; heard her confess the Crime, and vow repentance; here, in this very place: but by what means they 'scapt, I only can admire, not imagine.—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Prethee hold thy peace; I say once more 'tis only a Maggot:— Sleep, Fool, and purge thy head from fancies. How now, Ned?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Sir, I know not whether the News I bring may please you; but I have made a strange discovery yonder.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Discovery! of what prethee?—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Sir, I saw Rashley and your Wife— going laughing Arm in Arm through the Entry— the Backside of the Kitchin into the Parlour,— where, if you please to give your self the trouble, you may find 'em.—

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: This is as my Mistriss suspected, and I'll inform her immediately.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Hey day! My Wife and Rashley? Art sure on't, Ned?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: As sure, Sir, as I live, I saw 'em there:— nay, what's more, my curiosity inducing me to peep through the Key-hole, I saw his Head lie in her Lap,— whilst she with a fond passion strok'd his Cheeks, and dalli'd with his Hair: Faith, Sir, I could not see this and be silent; but you I fear will think the worse of me for it.—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: In the Parlour, sayst thou? 'Sbud, was ever such a confusion? Why, my Sister says that within these two minutes she saw and spoke to 'em here in this Chamber. They are here, and there, and every where, and yet I can find 'em no where; what a Pox shou'd a man think of this?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: They are there this instant, Sir, upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sure, I have not dreamt all this while! Did I not see here ●● by Heav'n I saw the Devil in her likeness then.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Why, peace, I say,— if you are mad, offend no one but your self with it.— What a Pox shall I not believe my eyes? The House is not haunted that I know of, unless it be with Fools:— There's a Bob for you by way of Conclusion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, Cuckolds too! There's a Bob for you by way of Repartée.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Cuckold?— I'd have you to know I scorn your words;— and were you not my Sister, I'd fetch you out with your Repartées. What, because you are a Fool, you guess all persons are alike?— Do you but conceive me, Mrs. Iuniper? I am a Turk at matter of fact when I see occasion.—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Good Sir,— no more of this,— but go down and satisfie your self in the truth of my Story:— if I tell you a Lye, call me Fool,— Horse,— any thing,— do but go and see.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: 'Sbud, I know not what to do: One brings me up, another carries me down; one jilts me, another abuses me; a third laughs at me;— and yet I find nothing, nor see nothing,— nor know nothing,— and you are nothing but Fools to make all this stir about nothing. But come, I'll go with thee, Ned.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And I, that I may say once in my life I saw a Miracle.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: I have her once more in the Noose of the slip; now the Devil hold her fast in th' other World:— 'Tis above mortal power! Come, Sir.—

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage:
Enter Rashley and Emilia in Night-Gowns,
Betty, Jeremy
.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: HEre, here, quickly take my Night-Gown, and put it on, you are sure they are coming.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Very sure, Madam;— I stood at the door and heard all.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: What must I do, Sweet?— Prethee do not let us be surpriz'd agen.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Uncase, uncase, Sir;— and let your Man represent you as Betty does me: Ieremy, be sure you play your part well, and Court her to the life.—

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: D'ee hear, Sirrah!

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, Sir. Come, Mrs. Betty.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Stay, a word more in thy ear:— I see this Fellow is but a Blockhead, and therefore am afraid of trusting him too far:— Keep him as ignorant of our Intrigue as thou canst; and if my Husband ask where I am, tell him I am gone to visit my Lady Courtly:— I'll be in my Chamber;— and when they are all gone, bring me word what Ranger and Maria are doing.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I'll be very careful.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: I will reward thy care, my pretty little—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Hark! I hear 'em coming;— now to your postures.—

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Now, Mrs. Betty, we having so fit an occasion, let us make Love in some Heroick Vein.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: No, I am for the plain-dealing way.—

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Pish! t'others a great deal better, as thus:
sp.l: Your Eyes with so bright Charms are deckt about,
That I could kiss 'em till I kist 'em out.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Oh I hate that;— I vow 'tis very silly.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: There, there, Sir;— D'ee see 'em now? will you believe next time?

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: O dismal Object!— I am a Cuckold then.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This is miraculous; how was it possible they cou'd get hither? But I am glad they are here however.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Now for a good full blow at his head before he sees me: 'tis a Cuckolds way of revenge I'm sure; Have at him!—

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Oh Lord, what mean you, Sir, what mean you?

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Traytor! Rogue! Rascal! I'll— Hah, Ieremy?

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, 'tis I, poor Ieremy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And Betty in her Mistrisses Night-Gown.—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Their old Friend the Devil has fetcht 'em away agen.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: What make you here in their Night-Gowns?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Only, Sir, through an ambition to make Love as Gentilely as we cou'd.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Go, go, and find your Mistriss out, and tell her, Her humble Servant and Husband desires to speak with her.— Look ye, Ned, you are a Fool, I see.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: I am so, Sir, I acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: And you, Madam, are a little leaning that way, are ye not?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I can say nothing for my self, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Then I can say y'are a Couple of Fools: Did I not tell you what all this wou'd come to? Ha, ha, ha! It makes me laugh to think how busie you two Asses have been about nothing; and I am no better than a third Fool for believing you: But from henceforth, he that speaks against my Chickens Vertue, is the Son of a Whore; for 'Uds Bood she's the honestest Woman in Christendom, and he that denies it, I will immediately invade him with Battle-Ax, Poinard and Pistol.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: She is a very Saint, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: A very Devil, Sir! O Death, is there no remedy?

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: I'll go instantly and reconcile my self to her, with a strict Vow never to doubt her more.— Oh Sir Roger! welcome.
Faith! I was wishing for some good Company to be Witness of my Reconcilement to my dear Chicken. You are melancholy, Sir,— I heard your Nephew was sick, I suppose that's the cause.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: If he has heard of what, I am disgrac'd for ever.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Come, Sir, cheer up, cheer up, he will be well agen, doubt not.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: I hope so, Sir. Madam, this Generous Act of concealing the infamy of our Family, has so wrought upon me, that if I cou'd requite—

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: No more, Sir:— Your Nephews forbearance is all I desire: You are sensible now that I have some reason to request that.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: I am, Madam, and am extreamly bound to your Generosity; and Gad I have another Nephew whom I'll make better by 200 l. a year to make you amends.— Well, Mr. Bubble, I am glad to come at so good a time, when mirth is going forward: you are a merry man, Sir,— and in verity I like your company.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: And I yours, Sir Roger;— for I am very merry for some private reason best known to my self:— We'll toss a Bumper about by and by, Faith!

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: An old Cronee, a Sorceress;— What ifack, and in the Devils Name, am I to be popt in the mouth with Fourscore and Twelve? A Beldame, a Witch, that expects next Winter to be turn'd into a Gib-Cat,— thought fit to be yok'd with me! No, no, some wiser than some; and I'll have her know within this week that I am as fit for Two and Twenty, as Two and Twenty is for me:— In the mean time avaunt Iezabel,— I like thee not, Icod; thou hast no black o' Top, ifack, thou art not for my turn.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: What, old Signior Fumble? what's the matter, Man?

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Yes marry am I, Sir, and chows'd damnably too, and some shall know't when I can find 'em.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: He's groping for his Spectacles; now I expect to be rated.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Ah,— are you there, Rogue, are you there! Why, you very Wag, wou'd you offer to serve me so? But hang thee, thou'rt a Rogue, and come ifack tho' 'twas a Knavish Trick, I am pleas'd with the Wit on't:— Give me thy hand, and come and kiss me, and all shall be well agen.—

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Upon condition you never trouble me more,— there 'tis.—

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Icod, she has a pretty Touch with her, she has ifack; I forgive thee with all my heart.— Well, old Woman, depart in peace; old Woman, I say, depart, and trouble me no more:— I am busie, and cann't dispence with the Fopperies of Age now.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Well, this comes of eating Sweet-meets when I was young: He had never found out the trick, if my want of Teeth had not discover'd me.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Ha, ha!— Here had like to have been fine sport ifaith:— but wou'd I knew where my Wife is, that we might all go and address, now I am in this good humour.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Sir, just as I came in, I saw her go up into her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Didst thou? I am glad on't ifaith: Come, let's all go.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Sir, I cannot find her; but I heard her say about an hour since, she intended to go and visit my Lady Courtly.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: No, no;— I know where she is now:— Poor Creature! I warrant she sits so melancholy above now.— Well,— I dare proudly say I have the best Wife in Christendom: for ifaith I have been very jealous of her, but I was wrought upon,— when o' my Conscience the innocent Wretch wou'd not hurt a Worm:— But come, we'll all go to her, and be sure, Sir Roger, you plead for me;— in troth my heart akes to think how I have us'd her.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I must prevent their going up, or we are undone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Whither are you runing? I have some bus'ness with you.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Good Madam, I'll wait on you immediately.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ye shall not stir till I have spoke to you:— Here must be something in this I find by her eagerness to be gone.

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Bubble,— in verity I'll do my best in your behalf; my Tongue is at your service at any time.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Sir Roger, you will oblige me in't.— She is the most innocent, sweetest, and most vertuous Person in the whole World, and I shall never be able to make her amends.— Come, let us go.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Now will I see how she behaves her self, and wonder at the prosperous Impudence Hell has endow'd her with, tho' it lies not in my power to repel it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now I think better on't, I'll defer my bus'ness till another time:— You may go where you please.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: This cunning Devil has undone 'em;— nor lies it now in my power to hinder it.— Oh I cou'd Curse—

div.head: Scena ultima.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: THe Plague of living with such a Husband you must imagine is very disagreeable to my Temper;— and were it not for the happy hours I have the good fortune to enjoy in thy society, my Life wou'd be wholly uncomfortable:— But, my Dear, thou wilt forget me, one day I shall grow cheap to thee, shall I not?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
No, never,— never, my Sweet!— Thou hast more Charms each hour added to thee, rather than one diminisht.— Forget thee! I sooner shall forget to feed my self, or that the Sun ere shone in
midst of Summer, than thy more precious Favours. Thou bring'st each hour new Sweets, and every minute a thousand thousand Graces throng about thee, my Dear,— Dear, Charming, Sweet,— Precious!—

div.stage:
Enter Bubble, Sir
Roger, Fumble, Ranger, Maria, Cordelia.

sp.speaker: Bubble entring.
sp.p: Softly, softly, Sir Roger: Poor Soul,— I warrant she's at Prayers.— Hah! what's this I see?— Gad jidge me—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: By Heav'n, they're here a Kissing!— Oh happy minute!

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Ah, who could have the heart to leave thy Blisses for such a Fool, such a Beast, such a dull, sordid, filthy, insipid Creature as my Husband?

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: How's that? Oh Devil!

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: I am smother'd with thy Charms; Oh for some Air! Hah!— Oh horrour, curs'd minute! taken thus?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: My Husband! Nay then I am lost for ever.—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Ah cursed Creature! is this thy Vertue?— But I'll—

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, in verity that must not be; No Swords against Women in my Company.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Then here let my Vengeance light. Traytor! have I oblig'd thee so often for this?— Have at thee!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Your pardon, Sir, I must hinder dishonourable proceedings; in the Field you may do what you please.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Speak, Witch, speak! what reason hadst thou to use me thus? Thou Limb of the Devil,— speak, I say.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Use you thus?— Why,— Sir, your Rage makes you suggest strange thoughts without cause. My kindness to Mr. Rashley was only because— he promis'd to be my Friend in urging my Reconcilement with you;— and because I knew he was your Friend, I therefore— I say, because I knew you lov'd him, I desir'd him to— to— I was very urgent with him— about— about— No I mistake! 'twas he was urgent with me to intreat you to do me the favour— no— to do him the favour: I mean, hum— to— to—

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Pox! what a Story's here? Oh Strumpet! Witch!—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: To Cuckold him, was that it, Sister?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Madam, me thinks your speech fails you exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: All will not do; O spiteful minute! Taken thus at last? Shame ties my Tongue, and absence is most necessary.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p: Oh farewel in the Devil Name! Oh Horns! Horns! found a Cuckold at last! I have spun a fair Thread, by the Lord Harry; A Cuckold at last!—

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
A Cuckold! Why, Sir,— have I done any thing but by your
directions?— Why do you suggest such things to your self?— Well, Sir, if I have injur'd you, I wear a Sword, Sir,— and so— Farewel.—

sp.speaker: Sir Rog.
sp.p: In verity his was a strange discovery;— but such things will happen— sometimes.—

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: So it seems; yet this me thinks is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p:
Oh unfortunate Husband! Well,— I'll go instantly and get a Divorce, and spend the remainder of my Life in penning a Satyr against Women;— I'll call it,
A CAUTION FOR CUCKOLDS
; where I will deplorably set down my own Case, and as a Warning-piece for rash young men, and for the benefit of my Country.

p.foreign: Felix quem faciunt aliena Cornua Cautum.

sp.speaker: Fumb.
sp.p: Something is the matter now, if I cou'd guess: But mum! I must not yet discover my failing.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Now the mighty Sophistress is o'erthrown!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thank Chance for that;— but no Wit of our own.—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Right, Madam; and by this a Man may see how unnecessary a thing it is,— to strive to turn the current of a Womans fancy, when it is bent to another. 'Tis a damn'd thing this Wenching, if a Man considers seriously on it; and yet 'tis such a damnable Age we live in, that, Gad, he that does not follow it is either accounted sordidly unnatural, or ridiculously impotent.— Well, for my part henceforward this shall be my Resolution:
sp.l: I'll Love for Interest, Court for Recreation;
Change still a Mistriss to be still in fashion:
I'll aid all Women in an Amorous League;
But from this hour ne'er baulk a Love-Intrigue.

div.head: EPILOGUE
div.l: WEll, Gentlemen, how d'ee?— Icod you sit,
As if you had no Souls, no Brains, no Wit.
What, not a word now in the Poets praise?
Hah!— Faith, I was a Spark in my young days.—
I Clapt, and Clapt;— nay, sometimes to my cost:
I Clapt so long,— Gad, I (was) Clapt at last.
There I was waggish;— You know what I mean;—
The Devil was in't, a Plaguy Yorkshire Quean.—
But 'tis no matter,— 'twas but thought a Iest,
And, Gad, I was as brisk then as the best.
So I am now; for Ifack I'd have you know,
Your Old Man, though he only serve for show,
Yet give him a Young Wench with Black o' Top,—
And you shall see him Frisk, and Iump, and Hop;—
Icod, and Wriggle!— Hah!— th' old Bell will sound,
Though there is ne'er a Clapper to be found.
But let that pass: Now your Applause disburse;
Why,— what the Devil makes you silent thus?—
What say ye,— The Play does not deserve it?— Hah!—
Icod, you are mistaken:— for I'll tell ye,
I once could Write and Iudge,— and ' Fack did do
Very strange things;— but I've forgot 'um now:—
But I remember what a Wag— I was:—
I had so many Smutty Iests those days,
I could get none but Women to my Plays.
But that's all one;— Icod, the Youth that Writ,
Does well;— and who knows,— may do better yet:
Therefore you should incourage him, D'ee hear?
And he that fails, I wish this Curse may bear,
That he be really my Character,—
Lascivious, Deaf, and Impotent as I;

And Gad that's Plague enough,— and so
God bu'y
.
